Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Mother’s improved housing and employment conditions eliminate the primary reasons the Court initially limited her parenting time and primary residential responsibilities, and thus constitute a material change in circumstances directly relevant to the Child’s well‑being.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The case does recognize that a material and substantial change in circumstances can justify modification of custody, and here the change was the mother’s rehabilitation from alcohol and drug dependence. However, the opinion does not discuss improved housing or employment as the material change, nor does it say such changes ‘eliminate the primary reasons’ custody was limited. The material change found was specifically her success in overcoming substance abuse, not broader socioeconomic improvements, so the case does not support the proposition as framed.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “In allowing the wife’s complaint for modification, the judge cited as a material and substantial change in circumstances, the wife’s ‘great success in overcoming her alcohol and drug dependence.’ … the wife’s progress in this regard, since the divorce decree granting temporary physical custody of the twins to the father, was supported by evidence in the record. Hence, the finding that a material and substantial change in circumstances had occurred was not clearly erroneous.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 266 (2001) (child’s wishes may be considered in custody determinations)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The Child’s evolving preferences, given her age and maturity, are an appropriate and important consideration in determining her best interests.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly notes that the child, Caleb, expressed a preference to reside primarily with his mother, and the court treats this preference as a relevant (though not dispositive) factor bearing on his best interests. By citing Ardizoni v. Raymond for the proposition that a child’s stated preference is not dispositive but still relevant, the court affirms that a child’s evolving wishes, given age and maturity, are an appropriate consideration in custody/best-interest determinations.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “In addition, we note that Caleb expressed to the guardian ad litem at the outset of the investigation his preference to reside primarily with his mother, and he reiterated this preference at the conclusion of the investigation, shortly before trial. Although not dispositive of the custody issue, Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738-739 (1996), these factors, at the very least, suggest that Caleb might quickly readjust to living with his mother during the week, and visiting his father on weekends and during part of each school vacation.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.proposition: The Child’s evolving preferences, given her age and maturity, are an appropriate and important consideration in determining her best interests.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion is centrally about weighing competing adoptive placements under a best-interests analysis for a very young child, but it does not discuss the child’s own preferences, nor age/maturity-based weight to the child’s expressed wishes. Hugo is four years old and there is no indication that the court considered any stated preference from him as a factor. Thus, while it elaborates the best-interests standard, it does not establish that a child’s evolving preferences are an appropriate or important consideration.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.relevant_excerpt: "Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’... [T]he weight to be accorded its several considerations... will vary with the circumstances."

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 402–03 (1981) (recognizing that children’s needs change with age)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: The Child’s needs have changed significantly as she has grown from a four‑year‑old preschooler at the time of the 2016 Order to a ten‑year‑old elementary school student, requiring increased emotional support, academic support, and time with both parents.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion is a custody and property division case and does not discuss how children’s needs evolve or change with age. Its custody analysis focuses on parental conflict, joint vs. sole custody, and the best-interests standard, not on developmental changes in a child’s needs over time. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that a child’s needs have significantly changed as she has grown older and now requires increased emotional, academic support, and time with both parents.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: In deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare... It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the children in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future, and it is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.proposition: These material changes were not and could not reasonably have been anticipated at the time of the 2016 Order, thereby satisfying the legal standard for modification.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.support_reasoning: The opinion does restate the Massachusetts standard that modification requires a material change in circumstances, but it does not say that the change must be something that was not and could not reasonably have been anticipated at the time of the prior order. The court instead focuses on whether there was a substantial/material change in circumstances and whether the payor still had the ability to pay, ultimately finding no sufficient change; it never articulates an ‘unanticipated change’ requirement. Thus, the case does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). In this case, the judge held that Chester did not prove the requisite change of circumstances.”

Katz v. Katz, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 472, 477.raw_text: Katz v. Katz, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 472, 477–78 (2002)
Katz v. Katz, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 472, 477.proposition: These material changes were not and could not reasonably have been anticipated at the time of the 2016 Order, thereby satisfying the legal standard for modification.
Katz v. Katz, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 472, 477.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on whether the trial judge abused her discretion in terminating alimony, emphasizing equitable balancing, ability to pay, and use of assets. It does not analyze or apply any requirement that the changes in circumstances be unanticipated at the time of an earlier order, nor does it discuss foreseeability or reasonable anticipation as part of the modification standard. Accordingly, it does not support a proposition that material changes were not and could not reasonably have been anticipated as a legal prerequisite to modification.
Katz v. Katz, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 472, 477.relevant_excerpt: “Notwithstanding the breadth of discretion possessed by Probate Court judges when dealing with complaints for modification of alimony pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 37… the termination of Charlotte’s alimony constituted, on this record, an abuse of that discretion and legal error. The judge failed to evaluate and balance, fairly and equitably… all of the circumstances relevant to the totality of the parties’ situations… and to keep in mind ‘the fundamental purpose of alimony: to provide economic support to the dependent spouse.’”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 208, § 31, and related case law, the paramount consideration in any custody and parenting‑time determination is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies and quotes G.L. c. 208, § 31 and related provisions in the context of a custody and parenting‑time dispute, and its analysis is framed in terms of what arrangement is appropriate in light of the child’s welfare, particularly the impact of domestic violence. While the excerpt focuses more on the statutory requirement for explicit findings in domestic‑violence situations than on restating the general "paramount consideration" formula, the court’s reasoning assumes and applies the “best interests of the child” standard as the controlling test for custody and visitation. Thus it is consistent with and supportive of the proposition, even if it does not contain a canonical phrasing of it in the quoted portion.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The Legislature reached a similar conclusion in respect to shared legal or physical custody. General Laws c. 208, § 31, provides that ‘[i]f, despite the prior or current issuance of a restraining order against one parent pursuant to chapter two hundred and nine A, the court orders shared legal or physical custody . . . the court shall provide written findings to support such shared custody order.’ … We agree with the Appeals Court that such written findings should also be made attending specifically to the effects of domestic violence on the child and the appropriateness of the joint custody award in light of those effects.”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191\.proposition: In determining best interests, the Court may consider, among other factors: the child’s past and present relationship with each parent; each parent’s ability to meet the child’s needs; the stability of each household; the child’s emotional ties; the child’s adjustment to home, school, and community; and, where appropriate, the child’s preferences.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191\.support_reasoning: The opinion mentions the "best interests" standard and notes that all relevant factors must be weighed, but it does not enumerate specific factors such as the child’s relationships, household stability, emotional ties, adjustment, or preferences. The court’s discussion is instead focused on child support, SSDI credits, asset attachment, and the lack of detailed findings supporting a custody modification. Thus, it does not provide the detailed list of best-interest factors described in the proposition.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191\.relevant_excerpt:
However, we shall not sustain an award of custody "unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed." Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981), citing Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555, 556 n.5 (1980). See King, supra, and cases cited.

… However, the judge "failed to make specific or detailed findings based on evidence within the record" that awarding sole legal custody of the minor child to the defendant was in the best interests of the child.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.proposition: In determining best interests, the Court may consider, among other factors: the child’s past and present relationship with each parent; each parent’s ability to meet the child’s needs; the stability of each household; the child’s emotional ties; the child’s adjustment to home, school, and community; and, where appropriate, the child’s preferences.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the general "best interests of the child" standard and emphasizes stability, continuity, primary caregiver status, and statutory factors under G.L. c. 209C, §10(a). However, it does not set out or endorse the specific multi-factor list in the claimed proposition (past and present relationship with each parent, household stability, emotional ties, adjustment to home/school/community, and child’s preferences). Any overlap (e.g., stability, parental ability to meet needs) is incidental rather than a clear articulation of that list, so the case does not directly support the proposition as stated.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child. … There may be serious shortcomings in the primary caretaker’s parenting to date… Or… the other parent may offer some extraordinary advantage to the child that makes the disruption in the child’s life worth the risk.”

Bercume v. Bercume, 428 Mass. 635, 641\u.raw_text: Bercume v. Bercume, 428 Mass. 635, 641–42 (1999) (emphasizing the importance of fostering relationships with both parents where appropriate)
Bercume v. Bercume, 428 Mass. 635, 641\u.proposition: Maintaining the current, highly limited parenting‑time schedule, which was crafted for circumstances that no longer exist, unnecessarily restricts the Child’s relationship with Mother and causes the Child emotional distress, which is contrary to the Child’s best interests.
Bercume v. Bercume, 428 Mass. 635, 641\u.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns modification of alimony after a merged separation agreement and the effect of merger versus survival; it does not address parenting time, custody, or fostering a child’s relationship with either parent. There is no discussion of best interests of a child in the context of visitation or parenting schedules, nor any language about emotional distress from limited parenting time. Using this case to support a proposition about revising a parenting-time schedule to foster the child’s relationship with a parent misstates its holding and subject matter.
Bercume v. Bercume, 428 Mass. 635, 641\u.relevant_excerpt: “A party seeking to modify a judgment for alimony or child support ‘must demonstrate a material change in circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.’ Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981)... In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances.” (Bercume, 428 Mass. at 643).

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and § 31, and cases such as Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), and Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), the Court has broad discretion to modify custody and parenting time when a material change of circumstances has occurred and the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman deals with a removal/relocation dispute under G.L. c. 208, § 30 where parents share joint legal and physical custody; it articulates that ‘upon cause shown’ means removal must be in the child’s best interests and is reviewed for abuse of discretion. The opinion does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 208, § 28 (modification of judgments) or § 31 (custody definitions and standards), nor does it discuss the ‘material change of circumstances’ standard for modifying custody or parenting time. Thus, citing Mason as authority that the court has broad discretion under §§ 28 and 31 to modify custody upon a material change of circumstances misstates its holding.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not… be removed out of this Commonwealth… without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’… Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and § 31, and cases such as Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), and Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), the Court has broad discretion to modify custody and parenting time when a material change of circumstances has occurred and the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: Yannas is a removal/relocation decision under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a modification case under §§ 28 and 31. The opinion discusses standards for initial custody determinations and for permitting a custodial parent to relocate children out of the Commonwealth, but it does not address the court’s authority or standard to modify existing custody or parenting time orders based on a material change of circumstances. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific modification proposition asserted.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”
